Coating-modified foam ceramic catalysts for ethyl nicotinate hydrogenation Fuxin Liang Methodology Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a Yulin Wei Visualization Formal analysis a Yuhang Du Validation Data curation a Fan Yang Funding acquisition d Zhe Pang Validation Investigation a Haochen Dang Methodology Formal analysis a Junyan Wu Funding acquisition a Sai Huang Project administration a Honglei Wang Funding acquisition b Qinggang Li Funding acquisition c Chao Wu Funding acquisition e Zhi Wang Visualization Supervision Funding acquisition a Guopu Shi Writing – review & editing Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ a School of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, China School of Materials Science and Engineering University of Jinan Jinan 250022 China aSchool of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, China b Anhui Dexinjia Biopharm Co., Ltd, Fuyang 236600, Anhui, China Anhui Dexinjia Biopharm Co., Ltd Fuyang Anhui 236600 China bAnhui Dexinjia Biopharm Co., Ltd, Fuyang 236600, Anhui, China c Suzhou Laboratory, Suzhou 215123, China Suzhou Laboratory Suzhou 215123 China cSuzhou Laboratory, Suzhou 215123, China d Guangxin Testing and Certification Group Co., LTD, China Guangxin Testing and Certification Group Co., LTD China dGuangxin Testing and Certification Group Co., LTD, China e Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Structural Materials and Application Technology, Nanjing Institute of Technology, Nanjing, 211167, China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Structural Materials and Application Technology Nanjing Institute of Technology Nanjing 211167 China eJiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Structural Materials and Application Technology, Nanjing Institute of Technology, Nanjing, 211167, China ⁎ Corresponding author. In drug synthesis, ethyl nicotinate hydrogenation is commonly performed to prepare ethyl 3-piperidine-carboxylate. For this hydrogenation, it is crucial to explore a catalyst with high catalytic activity and selectivity to form the desired product. To this end, a series of Pd/Al2O3-SiO2 catalysts with various SiO2 contents were prepared via coprecipitation on the surface of foam ceramics. We investigated the effect of SiO2 incorporation on the physical and chemical properties of the catalysts, such as specific surface area, pore structure, number of acidic sites, metal–support interactions, and catalytic activity. The addition of Si was found to weaken the metal–support interactions, facilitate the reduction of PdO, provide more metal sites, and increase the catalytic efficiency of catalyst. The effects of temperature and pressure on the hydrogenation reaction were also investigated, and under optimal reaction conditions, product yields of up to 85.53 % were achieved. This study offers a novel approach for the catalytic hydrogenation of ethyl nicotinate using carrier-modified metal–acid catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Piperidine-3-carboxylate Co-precipitation method Acidic site Pd catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethyl 3-piperidine-carboxylate is a crucial intermediate both in chemical and drug syntheses, as exemplified by its role in synthesis of γ-aminobutyric acid uptake inhibitors and pro-intellectual drugs for neurological disorders [1–3]. Additionally, it contributes to the synthesis of growth hormone secretagogues, trypsin-like inhibitors, and platelet aggregation inhibitors [4,5]. Hydrogenation of ethyl nicotinate to form ethyl 3-piperidine-carboxylate, a conventional synthesis pathway, has received increasing interest for its potential to achieve enhanced conversion of and selectivity for 3-piperidine-carboxylate. Nonhomogeneous catalysts, favored for their ease of separation and recovery in various catalytic reactions, include noble metal (palladium (Pd), platinum (Pt), rhodium (Rh), and ruthenium (Ru))-loaded catalysts and have been reported for this specific transformation [6–13]. Foam ceramics, known for their low cost, corrosion resistance, and temperature stability, have emerged as potential candidates as catalyst carriers. Wei et al. [14] performed catalytic CO2 methanation and CO oxidation by forming a Ce-P/γ-Al2O3 coating onto foam ceramics. The conversion of and selectivity for ethyl nicotinate were notably influenced by the active metals employed and the reaction conditions. Feldkamp et al. [15] obtained 75 % yield using PtO2 as a catalyst and acetic acid as the solvent; however, the presence of acetic acid resulted in the N-acetylation reaction, resulting in decreased selectivity to form the desired product. Miyamura et al. [16] successfully hydrogenated ethyl nicotinate using Pt/γ-Al2O3 under mild conditions at 50 °C. However, despite these efforts, yield of ethyl 3-piperidine-carboxylate typically lingers at ∼70 %, indicating that modification via metal alone does not substantially enhance the output. For supported catalysts, the carrier's physical and chemical properties play a pivotal role in catalyst activity, with factors such as acidity, specific surface area, and pore structure notably influencing the dispersion and particle size of the metal of the catalyst. γ-Al2O3, a widely used catalyst carrier, is favored for its high specific surface area and rich acid–base sites in various catalytic reactions. However, robust interactions between the metal and carrier result in insufficient reduction of metal oxides and fewer metal sites, notably affecting catalytic efficiency [17–19]. Addressing this challenge, Li et al. [20] developed a Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for the dehydrogenation of fully hydrogenated N-propyl carbazole, yielding only 78 % PdO, as the strong metal–carrier interactions of γ-Al2O3 inhibited the reduction of high-valent Pd. SiO2 serves as a catalyst carrier that weakly interacts with metals, rendering metal oxides loaded on SiO2 more readily reducible. However, this may compromise metal dispersion, resulting in fewer acidic sites on the surface. Kong et al. [21] observed a notably lower acidic site content in Co/SiO2 in comparison with Co/γ-Al2O3. Notably, γ-Al2O3/SiO2 composite oxides, which exhibit a large specific surface area and suitable metal–support interactions, have not been explored as a novel catalyst carrier for hydrogenation of ethyl nicotinate. Moreover, γ-Al2O3/SiO2 composite oxides offer abundant acidic sites for enhanced catalytic performance and selectivity to form desired product [22–26]. Consequently, this study employs the coprecipitation method to prepare a series of γ-Al2O3/SiO2 hybrid oxide carriers with varying SiO2 doping levels. Subsequently, foam ceramic-based Pd/γ-Al2O3/SiO2 catalysts are prepared via impregnation and labeled PA, PAS3/1, PAS2/1, PAS1/1, and PS. Effect of SiO2 doping on the specific surface area, surface acidity, metal dispersion, and particle size of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts is examined to evaluate the performance of the resulting Pd/γ-Al2O3/SiO2 catalysts in ethyl nicotinate hydrogenation reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Experimental materials Al(NO3)3·9H2O was provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ethyl orthosilicate (SiO2 content ≥ 40 %) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ammonia and glacial acetic acid was purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co. Palladium nitrate solution (Pd content of 4 wt%−5 wt%) was provided by Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co. 2.2 Preparation method The PASX catalysts were mainly prepared by a two-step method. The flowchart of the experiment is shown in Fig. 1 . Firstly, ASX carriers with different SiO2 contents (X is the molar ratio of Al and Si) were prepared by the co-precipitation method. The ASX carrier was prepared as follows: a certain amount of Al(NO3)3·9H2O was dissolved in 40 ml of distilled water and stirred for 15 min to obtain a homogeneous solution. Continuous stirring and adding 25 % ammonia solution drop by drop, adjusting the pH to 8.5–9.5, stirring at a constant temperature of 60 °C for 15 min, to obtain Solution A. Sodium silicate was dissolved in an aqueous ethanol solution and stirred for 15 min. During this time, 1.5 mol/L NH4Cl solution was added to produce a silicate precipitate. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 8.5 by the addition of ammonia, and the solution was then stirred for 60 min to obtain solution B. Solution B was slowly added to Solution A under rapid stirring conditions, and 50 ml of anhydrous ethanol was added, stirred at 60 °C for 2 h, adjusted pH to 8–9, sealed and stirred for 4 h The alumina foam ceramics prepared through organic foams were immersed into the mixture, evacuated to a vacuum of 0.6 MPa, immersed for 15 min, and repeated three times. Aged at room temperature for 24 h and dried at 100 °C for 12 h The obtained foam ceramic catalyst was calcined in a muffle furnace at 550 °C for 4 h to obtain the ASX carrier. All catalyst carriers were washed 4 times with deionized water. The PASX catalyst was prepared as follows: 1 g of palladium nitrate solution was dissolved in a certain amount of ammonia and sonicated for 20 min to obtain tetraammonium palladium nitrate solution. The PASX catalyst was obtained by slowly adding the foam ceramics to the tetra ammonium palladium nitrate solution in a water bath at 70 °C for 1 h and then dried in an oven at 100 °C. The catalysts were subjected to reduction treatment with H2 at 400 °C for 4 h 2.3 Catalyst characterization A Rigaku SmartLab 9 kW X-ray diffractometer (XRD) equipped with a Cu Kα monochromatic radiation source was used to characterize the prepared carriers and catalyst crystal orientations. Transmission electron microanalysis (TEM) was performed using a FEI Tecnai F20 system to observe the structure and metal distribution of the catalysts. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at 200 °C using Quantachrome Autosorb IQ for the evaluation of the specific surface area and pore size. The functional groups present in the Al2O3 and Al2O3-SiO2 catalysts were determined and analyzed using a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (Thermo, Nicolet iS10). The analyses were performed in absorption mode with 32 scans at 500–4000 cm-1. The adsorption and desorption properties of ammonia were determined on an AutoChem1II 2920 using the NH3 programmed temperature rise desorption (NH3-TPD) method. Firstly, 50 mg of the sample was weighed and placed in the reaction tube, and the temperature was increased from room temperature to 300 °C at 10 °C·min-1 for pre-treatment, He gas was purged for 1 h, 10 % NH3/He mixture (50 ml·min-1) was introduced for 1 h until saturation, and then switching to He gas stream purged for 1 h to remove physically adsorbed NH3 on the surface, and then the surface purged with NH3. Finally, the desorption was carried out under He atmosphere at a ramp rate of 10 °C·min-1 up to 700 °C, and the stripped gas was detected by TCD. The reduction property of Pd on Al2O3-SiO2 was evaluated using the H2 Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), similar to the NH3-TPD process described above. The chemical states and binding energies of the elements on the catalyst surface were determined using an ESCALAB Xi+ X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) with Al Kα radiation as the excitation source. All samples were reduced with H2 before XPS testing and glove box sampling was used to prevent sample oxidation. 2.4 Test for catalytic performance Ethyl 3-piperidine-carboxylate was synthesized in a TGYF-B stainless steel high-pressure reactor equipped with a magnetic stirring rotor. Ethyl nicotinate was used as the reactant and ethanol as the reaction solvent. 1 g of catalyst was weighed and 50 ml of reaction system including 1 ml of reactant. The reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatography and mass spectrometry (Agilent 7890A/GC-5975C). Conversion rate, selectivity, and yield are defined below: (1) Conversion ( % ) = n e n ( I n ) − n e n ( o u t ) n e n ( I n ) × 100 % (2) Selectivity ( % ) = n e p n e n ( I n ) − n e n ( o u t ) × 100 % (3) Yield ( % ) = Conversion × Selectivity Where nen represents the molar amount of ethyl nicotinate and nep represents the molar amount of ethyl 3-piperidine-carboxylate. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of physical properties of SiO2-modified Pd/Al2O3 catalysts 3.1.1 Catalyst composition and structure Fig. 2 (a) shows the XRD patterns of the catalyst supports with varying SiO2 doping levels. The diffraction peaks of the Al2O3 carrier at 37.48°, 45.62°, and 66.61° corresponded to the (311), (400), and (440) crystalline planes of γ-Al2O3, respectively. The diffraction peak of the SiO2 carrier at 22.01° corresponded to the (111) crystal plane of SiO2. In the modified carriers, a new diffraction peak appeared at between the γ-Al2O3 and SiO2 diffraction peaks, indicating formation of AS carriers. A comparison of the PDF standard cards showed that the carrier for AS2/1 corresponded to AlSi0.5O2.5. As seen from the XRD plots, intensity of the diffraction peaks of the γ-Al2O3 crystalline phase of the AS carrier was notably reduced with the peak shape broadened. This was primarily attributed to SiO2 inhibiting the aggregation of the small γ-Al2O3 particles into larger oxide particles during conversion of Al(OH)3 into γ-Al2O3, affording AS carriers with a larger specific surface area. Fig. 2(b) shows the XRD pattern of the Pd-loaded catalysts, for which almost no notable Pd peaks were observed, which was mainly attributed to the low loading of Pd associated with its high dispersion on the carrier [27]. However, with increasing SiO2 content, a diffraction peak of Pd appeared at 40.03°, corresponding to the (111) crystal plane of Pd, and its intensity gradually increased. This was mainly because SiO2 doping weakened the metal–support interaction, resulting in decreased metal particle dispersion and onset of agglomeration [28]. Fig. 3 shows the scanning electron microscope images of the PAS2/1 foam ceramic catalyst and its elemental distribution. These images demonstrate the microstructure as well as the elemental composition of the catalyst. As seen from Figs. 3(a) and (b), this catalyst exhibited a three-dimensional mesh structure, which not only provided abundant specific surface area but also a certain mechanical strength, which was very favorable for use, recycling, and reuse of the catalyst. In particular, designing such structures is of great importance in terms of environmental protection and resource utilization. Figs 3(c) and (d) clearly show that nano-PAS2/1 was attached as a coating on the surface of lamellar α-Al2O3 crystals, further confirming successful loading of the catalytic coating. This type of loading closely bonded the catalyst to the carrier, which helped enhance the stability and activity of the catalyst, thus achieving the catalytic reaction in a more efficient manner. Figs 3(e–g) show that the nanocatalyst coatings have the morphology of lamellar clusters with uniform distribution. This morphology may be closely associated with the high catalytic activity of the catalyst. This homogeneous and dense distribution helped increase the contact area between the catalyst and reactants, thus enhancing the reaction rate and efficiency. The distribution of the individual elements of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 3(h), and it is very homogeneous. Notably, this homogeneous distribution helped ensure the stability and consistency of the catalyst and, hence, the controllability and reproducibility of the catalytic reaction. Finally, Fig. 3(i) shows maps for the distribution of each element, where the aluminum (Al)/silicon(Si) atomic ratio is 2/1, consistent with the expected composition of the designed catalyst PAS2/1. The lower content of Pd, however, resulted in weaker XRD and elemental distribution signals, also consistent with the experimental results. These observations provided an important reference for further comprehending the catalyst's performance and design optimization. Fig. 4 shows the high-resolution transmission electron micrographs of PA and PAS2/1, particle size distribution of Pd, and energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) spectra of the individual elements. Comparing Figs. 4(a) and (c), one can see that the particle size distribution of Pd on the Al2O3 carrier was mainly concentrated at ∼3.5 nm particle size. Particle size of Pd reached 10 nm as Si content was increased, which was mainly attributed to SiO2 weakening the metal–support interaction between metallic Pd and Al2O3, resulting in aggregation of Pd. The (110) crystalline surface of PdO can be seen from Fig. 4(b); the lattice boundaries of PdO were observed to be blurred because it had been encapsulated by amorphous carriers during the reduction process, resulting in its inability to be completely reduced. Fig. 4(d) shows a more complete reduction of PdO due to weaker metal–support interactions exposing PdO to the catalyst's surface, which is consistent with the enhancement of Pd peaks observed in the XRD patterns. The EDS spectra in Figs. 4(e) and (f) reveal a relatively uniform distribution of all catalyst elements, with Fig. 4(f) indicating a higher exposure of Pd. 3.1.2 Specific surface area and pore size distribution of catalysts Fig. 5 (a) shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isothermal curves for the individual catalysts, all of which exhibit type IV adsorption isotherms, suggesting the presence of mesoporous structures in the samples. Compared with macropores, the abundant mesoporous structure could provide a more specific surface area and more contact opportunities for reactions, thus enhancing the catalytic efficiency. In addition, mesoporous structures can regulate molecular spacing within the reaction system, thereby enhancing selectivity for the reaction and reducing occurrence of side reactions. Fig. 5(a) shows that the PA, PAS3/1, and PAS2/1 catalysts exhibit H1-type hysteresis loops, while the PAS1/1 and PS catalysts show H3-type hysteresis loops, suggesting that the pore structure evolved with increasing SiO2 content. Fig. 5(b) shows the pore size distribution of each carrier. A bimodal distribution can be seen for the PS catalyst, with small pores (<5 nm) and large pores (10–60 nm), which accounts for the less prominent mesoporosity. The other carriers feature a pore size predominantly in the 1–10 nm range, with a notable mesoporous structure. Table 1 presents the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the five catalyst carriers, showing that these parameters initially increase and then decrease with SiO2 content. The higher specific surface area was attributed to the fact that introduction of SiO2 into Al(OH)3 suppressed to a certain extent the aggregation growth of Al2O3 particles during the roasting process, and the larger pore volume suggested that the SiO2 doping could alter the pore structure, which was consistent with results of the adsorption isotherm curves. The decrease in these two sets of parameters for the PAS1/1 catalyst indicated that the highly SiO2 doping partially clogged the Al2O3 pore structure. Conversely, the PS catalyst is mainly attributed to its large pore size. 3.2 Chemical characterization of SiO2-modified Pd/Al2O3 catalysts 3.2.1 Catalyst chemical composition X-ray photoelectron spectra of the 2p orbitals of Al and Si are shown in Figs. 6(a) and (b), respectively. As seen from Fig. 6 (a), the binding energy of elemental Al in the Al2O3 sample is 74.6 eV, whereas the binding energy of elemental Al in the PAS2/1 sample is consistent with that of Al in aluminosilicate, indicating that elemental Si has been successfully incorporated into the structure of Al2O3. The binding energy of Si in Fig. 6(b) is also consistent with this pattern. The Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum of Al2O3 is shown in Fig. 6(c), where a strong absorption peak is observed at 3460 cm−1, corresponding to the antisymmetric telescopic vibration of hydroxyl groups on the surface of Al2O3, which is an important source of acidity on the catalyst's surface. The absorption peak at 2400 cm−1 was ascribed to the vibrational peak of C = O in the CO2 impurity, and the peak at 1640 cm−1 was attributed to the telescopic vibration of OH (H2O), which physically adsorbs water [29,30]. The absorption peaks at 1400 and 800 cm−1 were attributed to absorption vibrational peaks of the Al–O bond. In contrast with Al2O3, the peaks at 1090 cm−1 in the FT-IR spectrum of AlSi0.5O2.5 were attributed to the Si–O–Si stretching vibration, while the absorption peaks at ∼460 cm−1 were ascribed to the bending vibration of the Si–O bond (Fig. 6d) [31]. Intensity of the absorption peak of the Al–O bond at 800 cm˗1 was observed to be diminished, indicating the substitution of Al atoms in the skeleton. The absorption peak at 970 cm˗1 was attributed to the local asymmetry of the skeleton resulting from substitution of Al by Si, which was the basis for determining the homogeneity of the Al2O3/SiO2 composite oxide carriers. We observed that the element Si had been successfully incorporated into the Al2O3 skeleton. 3.2.2 Acidic sites of catalysts In catalysis, acidic sites play a pivotal role in adsorption, activation, polarization, or dissociation of reactants, thereby facilitating the reaction. Fig. 7 (a) shows the NH3-TPD curves of the catalysts. The desorption peaks at 100 °C–200 °C, 200 °C–350 °C, and 350 °C–500 °C corresponded to weak, medium–strong, and strong acids, respectively. Clearly, one can see that SiO2 doping notably increased the acidic site content of the catalysts; this was not only because the carrier had a higher specific surface area and larger pore volume but also because Si4+ and Al3+ have tetrahedral structures, when the radius of Si4+ is almost the same as the replacement of Al3+, with Al3+ connected to the 3/4 valence, resulting in the absence of two valence units for each O2− requirement (Fig. 7b). In the aluminum–oxygen tetrahedron, there are four oxygens atoms and one valence unit is missing, thus forming a negative electric field. To maintain electrical neutrality, the Al3+ tetrahedral structure needs to be connected to a proton H +so as to neutralize the excess negative valence, in turn introducing an abundance of Brønsted acidic sites. For SiO2 carriers, only a small number of acidic sites were present, as they are electroneutral. For each catalyst, Table 2 presents the content of acidic sites, proportion of weak acids, and density of acidic sites. The table clearly shows that the proportion of weak acid in the catalysts was on a rise, and a suitable ratio between strong and weak acids was not only conducive to adsorption of reactants on the catalyst's surface but also enabled rapid detachment of the products, facilitating rapid progress of the reaction [32–35]. Content of acidic sites showed an increasing trend and then a decreasing trend with increase in SiO2 content. Replacement of Al atoms with Si atoms within the Al₂O₃ backbone resulted in a negative charge due to the lower valence state of Al in comparison with Si. The aforementioned negative charge was counterbalanced by the attractive force of protons (H +) during formation of Bronsted acid sites. A greater number of negative charges were observed as the quantity of Si atoms introduced into the system was increased, forming a greater number of B-acid sites. However, given that the coating skeleton was composed of SiO4 and AlO4 tetrahedra linked by shared oxygen atoms, this may reduce the structural stability of the skeleton as the proportion of Si atoms increases. Some structural changes may occur to maintain the stability of the skeleton, such as the formation of nonskeletal Si or extraskeletal Si species, which may reduce the number of acidic sites. Therefore, during preparation of carriers, a reasonable Al/Si ratio needs to be maintained to ensure optimal content and distribution of acidic sites. Furthermore, increase in Si content will increase the amount of negative charge, necessitating the presence of a greater number of protons to attain equilibrium. However, when Si atoms are in close proximity to one another, strength of the electrostatic interactions between them may increase, possibly resulting in challenges in stabilizing the protons in the backbone and, consequently, affecting the formation of acidic sites. Furthermore, with increase in Si content, the acidic site density notably increased in comparison with non-SiO2-doped catalysts, providing additional adsorption sites for the feedstock. 3.2.3 Effect of SiO2 on metal–support interactions Fig. 8 (a) shows H2-TPR curves of the catalysts with various SiO2 doping levels. All catalysts had been prereduced. The reduction peak temperature of Pd gradually decreased with increase in SiO2 content; the PA catalyst had the highest Pd reduction temperature of ∼365 °C. This higher reduction temperature was mainly attributed to the strong Pd (metal)–Al2O3 (carrier) interaction, which resulted in transfer of a portion of electrons from the carrier to Pd, affording negative charge to Pd and thus hindering its reduction. Introduction of SiO2 weakened this electron transfer, notably decreasing the onset and termination temperatures of Pd reduction. The PS catalyst exhibited two reduction peaks, which we hypothesize as a result of weak metal–support interaction, causing Pd particle agglomeration and slowing the reduction rate of PdO, thereby allowing for the reduction process to continue for a notable duration. Of all the catalysts, the reduction peak of the PAS2/1 catalyst generated the strongest signal, attributed to its suitable metal dispersion as well as metal–support interactions. This indicated the catalyst's strong H2 adsorption and activation capacities, which benefited hydrogenation of ethyl nicotinate. Furthermore, we integrated the H2-TPR curves of five catalysts at <400 °C (the temperature at which they were prepared) and calculated the corresponding integration areas. The specific data are presented in Table S1, which shows that the hydrogen consumption of the catalysts tended to increase and then decrease. The reduction of the metal Pd in the PAS2/1 catalyst was 76.43 %. A high reduction degree indicated that a greater number of metal ions were converted into metal atoms, which served as active centers and could more effectively interact with reactant molecules, thus facilitating the reaction. Furthermore, a catalyst with high degree of reduction can select reactant molecules with greater accuracy, hence reducing the occurrence of side reactions and thus enhancing selectivity. The chemical state of Pd on various catalyst surfaces was characterized via XPS. As shown in Fig. 8(b), the 3d5/2 peak of Pd was observed to be split into two peaks corresponding to the high- and low-valence states of Pd, respectively. For the PA, PAS3/1, PAS2/1, and PAS1/1 catalysts, the peaks with higher binding energies corresponded to PdO and those with lower binding energies corresponded to the metal Pd. We observed that PdO and the metal Pd moved in the direction of high binding energy as SiO2 content was increased. This mainly because introduction of SiO2 attenuated the metal–support interactions and thus transfer of electrons from the carriers to the metal Pd decreased, gradually increasing the binding energy of Pd. In addition, relative content of the metal Pd with respect to PdO could be indicated by peak area of the fitted peaks, and we observed that relative content of the metal Pd with respect to PdO increased with SiO2 content. This suggested that SiO2 had attenuated the metal–support interaction and reduced more PdO to Pd, as confirmed via transmission electron micrographs of the catalysts. The highest Pd metal content was observed to be in the PAS2/1 catalyst. At Al–Si ratio of 1/1, the fitted peak of low-valence-state Pd corresponded to PdOX (X < 1), which might be attributed to agglomeration of Pd particles resulting in insufficient reduction of PdO. The H2-TPR, XPS, and transmission electron microscopy diagrams showed that (a) SiO2 notably weakened the metal–support interactions and (b) the PAS2/1 catalyst delivered the highest H2 activation performance of all catalysts, which was related to its abundant Pd metal content and suitable metal dispersion. 3.3 Catalytic performance of SiO2-modified Pd/Al2O3 catalysts 3.3.1 Ethyl nicotinate hydrogenation mechanism Ethyl nicotinate, a common aromatic heterocycle, is crucial in drug synthesis, and comprehending its hydrogenation mechanism is critical to optimizing conversion of and selectivity for this compound. As shown in Fig. 9 , the reaction comprises four main steps. First, hydrogen is adsorbed and activated on the active sites (Pd) on the surface of the noble metal catalyst at the beginning of the reaction, a process typically involving interaction between hydrogen and the noble metal atoms on the surface of the catalyst to form an active hydrogenator. Simultaneously, Ethyl nicotinate is adsorbed onto the acid site of the Al2O3-SiO2 carrier via the nitrogen atom of the aromatic heterocycle and subsequently reacts with the hydrogen atom on the palladium metal to form ethyl 3-piperidine-carboxylate; the catalyst surface always tends to adsorb foreign species, thus bringing the system to the lowest energy state, helping reactants interact with the active sites. In the conversion process, the N-terminus is in an electron-rich state because of the presence of N atoms in ethyl nicotinate. The strong, inductive electron-withdrawal effect of the N atoms results in formation of positively charged C atoms at the α and γ sites, which is more favorable for nucleophilic substitution. At this time, the coating surface is replete with robust acidic sites on the ethyl nicotinate molecule, facilitating electrophilic attack, expediting the breakage of the C–H bond, and promoting the addition of activated hydrogen to ethyl nicotinate for specificity, thereby resulting in complete reduction of ethyl nicotinate. As the reaction proceeds, ethyl 3-piperidine-carboxylate is ultimately yielded. The product is desorbed from the catalyst surface at the conclusion of the reaction. Simultaneously, the active sites on the catalyst are released, enabling their continued participation in the reaction. 3.3.2 Effect of catalyst type and reaction conditions on yield Fig. 10 (a) shows the catalytic process for hydrogenation of ethyl nicotinate. First, 1 mL of ethyl nicotinate and the five catalysts, each with 0.1 wt.% Pd content, were sequentially placed in a 200-mL TGYF-B-type high-pressure reactor with 1:10 feed ratio; the reaction was performed at various temperatures and pressures for 18 h with 600 r•min˗1 stirring rate. The catalyzed liquid phase was removed from ethanol by means of a rotary evaporator to obtain crude ethyl 3-piperidine-carboxylate. The reacted foam ceramic catalyst could be continued to be used for the next reaction. As shown in Fig. 10(b), catalytic performances of the SiO2-doped catalysts were observed to be markedly enhanced under identical conditions, with the conversion of and selectivity for ethyl nicotinate reaching 99.12 % and 80.8 %, respectively. This was primarily attributed to the high specific surface area, numerous acidic sites, and high Pd content of the catalysts. Catalytic data for the remaining catalysts are presented in Table 3 . Metal dispersion of the catalysts was tested via CO pulse adsorption, and TOF values were calculated. Table 3 shows that the TOF values of the catalysts first increased and then decreased, although the metal dispersions exhibited a decreasing trend with increase in SiO2 content. The TOF value of the PAS2/1 catalyst reached 457.27, mainly attributed to its remarkable catalytic activity. The PAS2/1 catalyst was selected for further analysis, and the reaction temperature and pressure were varied to study their effect on its catalytic performance; the paticular data are presented in Table S2. As shown in Fig. S1, the conversion of ethyl nicotinate molecules by all catalysts exhibited a varying degree of increase with rise in reaction pressure within the 5–8 MPa range. The conversion by the PAS3/1, PAS2/1, PAS1/1, PA, and PS catalysts was observed to be enhanced by 11.85 %, 0.18 %, 14.74 %, 11.12 %, and 15.37 %, respectively. This was primarily because the rise in pressure increased the frequency of molecular collisions within the solution, resulting in a greater number of ethyl nicotinate molecules being excited and participating in the reaction, thereby increasing the conversion rate. Of the catalysts, PAS2/1 exhibited remarkable physicochemical properties, offering a consistently high conversion rate while requiring minimal catalyst enhancemen. Upon increasing the pressure to 7 MPa, dissolution of H2 in the liquid phase reached saturation, hence resulting in a negligible effect of further pressure increase on conversion rate. Furthermore, selectivity for the reaction remained largely unchanged with increase in pressure, indicating that pressure alterations exerted minimal effect on the selectivity for the reaction forming ethyl 3-piperidine-carboxylate. Overall, these findings suggested that 7 MPa may offer the optimal catalytic efficiency, as a result of which it was identified as the most suitable catalytic pressure. Catalytic performances of various catalysts were evaluated at different temperatures at 7 MPa pressure. As shown in Fig. S2, conversion of ethyl nicotinate did not notably increase with increase reaction temperature. This suggested that the conversion was not notably affected by temperature at 7 MPa. Selectivity of the different catalysts reached a maximum at 120 °C. However, it began to decline upon further increase in temperature. This was primarily because an excessively high reaction temperature facilitated generation of byproducts, reducing the selectivity to form the target products. To achieve the highest yield, 120 °C was identified as the optimal reaction temperature. As shown in Fig. 10(c), the catalyst exhibited a conversion rate exceeding 80 % following 10 cycles. In particular, the PAS2/1 catalyst showed good cycling stability. 4 Conclusion To obtain catalysts with high catalytic activity and easy recycling, foam ceramic-based catalysts with various SiO2 contents were prepared via coprecipitation. First, the catalysts exhibited remarkable physical properties, characterized by a larger specific surface area, a more mesoporous-abundant structure, and favorable chemical properties, including increased number of acidic sites and suitable metal–support interactions within the composite carriers. Second, introduction of SiO2 played a pivotal role in weakening the metal–support interactions, facilitating participation of more PdO in the reduction process thereof and providing additional Pd metal sites. Investigation of the mechanism of ethyl nicotinate hydrogenation reaction revealed a synergistic interaction between metal and acidic sites, enhancing catalytic efficiency. Upon exploring the effect of reaction temperature and pressure on the catalytic process, it was indicated that excessively high temperature and pressure favored generation of byproducts. Optimal reaction conditions were determined by mean of systematic analysis. We believe that this catalyst exhibited potential for commercial applications in efficiently catalyzing the hydrogenation of nitrogen-containing aromatics. coredata.dc:description: In drug synthesis, ethyl nicotinate hydrogenation is commonly performed to prepare ethyl 3-piperidine-carboxylate. For this hydrogenation, it is crucial to explore a catalyst with high catalytic activity and selectivity to form the desired product. To this end, a series of Pd/Al2O3-SiO2 catalysts with various SiO2 contents were prepared via coprecipitation on the surface of foam ceramics. We investigated the effect of SiO2 incorporation on the physical and chemical properties of the catalysts, such as specific surface area, pore structure, number of acidic sites, metal–support interactions, and catalytic activity. The addition of Si was found to weaken the metal–support interactions, facilitate the reduction of PdO, provide more metal sites, and increase the catalytic efficiency of catalyst. The effects of temperature and pressure on the hydrogenation reaction were also investigated, and under optimal reaction conditions, product yields of up to 85.53 % were achieved. This study offers a novel approach for the catalytic hydrogenation of ethyl nicotinate using carrier-modified metal–acid catalysts.
